description: From Middle English noughti, naughty (“evil, immoral, wicked; bungling, ineffectual; in want, needy; evil or hostile person”) [and other forms], from nought (“evil, immoral; of poor quality, worthless; unworthy; inappropriate, unsuitable; impotent, powerless, weak; useless; of an agreement, decree, or obligation: null, void; trivial; diseased”) + -ī̆ (suffix forming adjectives). Nought is derived from Old English nōwiht, nāwiht (“nothing”), from Proto-West Germanic *naiwwiht (“nothing”). The English word is analysable as naught +‎ -y.

entries.meaning: Mischievous; tending to misbehave or act badly (especially of a child). [from 17th c.]
examples: Some naughty boys at school hid the teacher's lesson notes.

entries.meaning: Sexually provocative; now in weakened sense, risqué, cheeky. [from 19th c.]
examples: I bought some naughty lingerie for my honeymoon.
If I see you send another naughty email to your friends, you will be forbidden from using the computer!

entries.meaning: (now rare, archaic) Evil, wicked, morally reprehensible. [from 15th c.]
examples: my proneſſe to ſinne, and naughty appetites and desires, woulde drawe me headlong to the pitte of hell

verbs.description: naughty (third-person singular simple present naughties, present participle naughtying, simple past and past participle naughtied)
